channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Junior Perl Developer who needs a career boost? London, UK
item.description: Taking the journey from Junior to Senior â€“ and building a strong work history â€“ is a lot more fun in the right job â€“ somewhere with a strong work environment, talented and friendly colleagues, and projects that actually have real-world impact.

item.title: Use Open Source Tools for a Righteous Cause (Artist Protection) in London
item.description: The music industry has changed drastically in the last twenty years. Free music reigns. That means, artistsâ€”at least those outside the mainstreamâ€“must work harder than ever to protect their lawful property. Copyright protection? Giggle, giggle. Itâ€™s simply not a priority for the biggest platforms (hello YouTube!).

item.title: Want to be as welcome as a Martian in Roswell? Perl developers in Houston Texas
item.description: Do you remember what you wanted to be when you grew up? Doctor? Rock star? Or maybe you were intrigued by a different sort of star . . . hello, Spacemen and Spacewomen! Calling all childhood astronautsâ€”if your passion for the space program morphed into a passion for Perl programming, then we have an opportunity thatâ€™s out of this world.

item.title: A Fang-tastic Opportunity in Manchester, UK
item.description: Picture this: Dracula is on the hunt for a flatmate. He takes a gamble on some shady guy from Craigslist, name of Van Helsing . . . and next thing you know, poor olâ€™ Drac is staked while he sleeps. But wait! Thereâ€™s a better way, and thatâ€™s where you come in.

item.title: A little bird told me this might be the job for you!
item.description: Pop quiz: Where can you go to enjoy an Indian curry, take in a concert, search out the perfect whiskey sour AND get paid? Weâ€™ll give you a hint: itâ€™s where our clientâ€™s office is located, and itâ€™s in one of the most accessible areas in London. One more hint? A little bird told me this might be the job for one dynamic Perl programmer . . .

item.title: Barcelon Perl and Friends 2019
item.description: November 9, 2019 in Barcelona, Spain. A free one-day conference for Geeks and Friends

item.title: London Perl Workshop 2019
item.description: October 19, 2019. David Game College, 31 Jewry St, London EC3N 2ET

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: Itch.scratch()
item.description: Damian is back again with another gem showing the power of Perl6 Grammar. Highy Recommended.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 26
item.description: Roger solution for Stones and Jewels task using just map{}. For mean angles task he used pure perl.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 26: Common Letters and Mean Angles
item.description: Laurent solution to the Mean Angles task is amazingly easy and simple to follow with unit test.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 026: Stones and Jewels; Mean of Angles
item.description: I liked the way, Choroba, used CPAN modules to solve the challenge.

item.title: Stones and Jewels
item.description: Welcome back Donald, after break, it was worth the wait.

item.title: String Angling with Perl 6
item.description: Arne making use of custom type for Stones and Jewels task is interesting. His use of diagram makes it follow the code.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 026
item.description: Adam, ex-Champion, came up with his unique blog. You can't afford to miss it.

item.title: Meet The Champion - Yet Ebreo
item.description: Please check out the short interview with the "Perl Weekly Challenge - 025" winner Yet Ebreo.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 026
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 027
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Perl Unicode versions
item.description: Tom shares very interesting stats about how Unicode progressed through various releases of Perl.

item.title: Pete Krawczyk nominated for TPF Treasurer
Henk Penning
item.description: Robert shares the news of demise of Henk "HPP" Penning.

item.title: Scripting the Dropbox API
item.description: Incredible implementation of Dropbox API by Dave. You can't afford to miss the writing.

item.title: Formal Request - Discourage Taint
item.description: Chase Whitener opens up discussion about the use of Taint in Perl.

item.title: Creating IP address tools from scratch
item.description: David came up with another great article explaining the secret of IP address.

item.title: Perl Newbies weekly update 2019/09/21
item.description: Yuki recently created "Perl Newbie" site and has been sharing weekly and monthly update. Please take a look at his recent weekly update.

item.title: Come to the London Perl Workshop, write better code!
item.description: LPW organisers started confirming talks. In the first series, they are talking about some of the talks that got confirmed.

item.title: #426 - Hacktoberfest - a week away
item.description:
Hi there

Two weeks ago, I mentioned in the editorial about twin events i.e. Hacktoberfest and London Perl Werkshop. It is nearly a week away before the Hacktoberfest kicks in. Team at Perl.com has been preparing for it rigorously. They have even created an issue #203 to discuss the subject. However you could take a look list of issues for the ideas for Hacktoberfest challenge.

London Perl Workshop has started process of confirming talks. If you are planning to attend then why not add to your personal schedule your favourite talks. This would help the organisers in scheduling the talks accordingly. If you have never given talk before and would like to give your first talk then please submit your proposal as soon as possible. The last date for submitting proposal is 30th September 2019.

Good luck for Hacktoberfest challenge and see you at the next London Perl Workshop 2019 event.

Have a great week ahead.
